How Long Does It Really Take to Prepare for an Interview?

On average, job seekers spend 5 to 10 hours preparing for an interview. But hereâ€™s the kickerâ€”itâ€™s not just about logging hours; itâ€™s about what you do with that time. Effective preparation can mean the difference between landing your dream job and walking away disappointed.

Hereâ€™s the good news: you can maximize your preparation time with a few targeted strategies.

3 Tips to Set Yourself Up for Success:

1) Do Your Homework: Research the companyâ€™s mission, values, and recent projects. Dive deep into the job description and connect the dots between what they need and what you bring to the table.

2) Practice Smart: Donâ€™t wing it! Practice answering common interview questions, but donâ€™t stop there. PRO-TIP: Record yourself, get feedback, and refine your responses to sound natural and confident.

3) Prepare to Connect: Beyond qualifications, interviewers want to see if youâ€™re a cultural fit. Come prepared with thoughtful questions about the role, team, or company that show youâ€™re genuinely interested and make impactful connections.

Remember, itâ€™s not about rehearsing every word but about being prepared enough to feel confident and adaptable. With the right approach, those 5 to 10 hours can transform into an offer!

Whatâ€™s your go-to interview prep tip? Let me know in the comments!

Ever walked out of an interview thinking,
â€œI couldâ€™ve answered that so much betterâ€ ğŸ¤” ?

Yeah, me too.

The truth is, most of us donâ€™t fail interviews because weâ€™re not good enough, we fail because we donâ€™t know how to communicate our value the right way.

And I learned this the hard way.

Back when I first started preparing for interviews, I thought â€œjust be yourselfâ€ was enough. But reality hit me fast. Interviews are a skill, and like any skill, you get better with practice.

One resource that helped me a lot was The Interview Guide School by Jason Kwok Yuan Long. Iâ€™ve had it for a long time. Here are some helpful tips you can take note of:

ğŸ”¹ Stop â€œdescribingâ€ your experience, start proving your impact.
Saying â€œI managed projectsâ€ isnâ€™t enough.
Instead, say:
â¡ï¸ â€œI led a team of 5 to complete a project 2 weeks ahead of schedule, saving 20% in costs.â€
Show the numbers, show the impact.

ğŸ”¹ Nail the â€œTell me about yourselfâ€ question.
This is NOT your autobiography.
Think of it as your 30-second personal brand pitch:
âœ… Who you are professionally
âœ… What you bring to the table
âœ… Why they should care

ğŸ”¹ Confidence is built before the interview
I used to overthink every answer, but preparation changed everything. Record yourself, practice with a friend, or even talk to yourself in the mirror (yes, Iâ€™ve done this). The more you practice, the less your nerves control you.

ğŸ”¹ Ask smart questions because youâ€™re also interviewing them.
At the end of the interview, donâ€™t just sit there waiting to be dismissed.
Ask:
â“ â€œWhat are the biggest challenges in this role?â€
â“ â€œHow do you define success in the first 6 months?â€
It shows confidence and makes them remember you.

At the end of the day, interviews are about impressing people with how well you fit the role.

Agree?


Happy Webnesday & stay safe â¤ï¸

If you get anxious before interviews, you're not alone! ğŸ‘‡

Interview nerves are super common. 93% of Americans feel stressed before an interview. Trying to make a good first impression while answering important questions is a lot to juggle.

Here are a few tips to help calm those pre-interview jitters:

ğŸ” Research
â†³ Preparation is a great way to calm your nerves. The more you know about the company and role, the more confident you'll feel.

âœï¸ Prepare Notes
â†³ Before your interview, print out your resume and job description to have as a quick reference. Jot down a few key points about the role, your experience, and your questions.

ğŸ’¬ Mock Interviews with Friends
â†³ The more you practice, the easier it gets! Doing mock interviews helps take the edge off and gives you a chance to rehearse your answers.

ğŸ§˜â€â™€ï¸ Take a few deep breaths
â†³ Calm down by taking some mindful breaths. Try the 4-7-8 technique to center yourself.

ğŸ’™ Say Affirmations
â†³ Positive affirmations work wonders for boosting your confidence and calming your nerves. Remind yourself of your value and abilities!

ğŸ—£ï¸ Speak Slowly
â†³ During the interview, speaking slowly will give you time to collect your thoughts. If you begin to feel anxious, pause and take a breath.

ğŸŒ  Don't Strive for Perfection
â†³ An interview is just a conversation! Trying to be perfect will only make you overthink. Focus on connecting with the interviewer instead.

Remember: It's completely normal to feel nervous! Your interviewer wants you to succeed. Trust in yourself - youâ€™ve got this. ğŸ’ªğŸŒŸ

post_html:
ğŸ‘¨ğŸ»â€ğŸ’¼Interview Tip: Remember, interviews go both ways. ğŸ‘©ğŸ½â€ğŸ’¼

While companies are evaluating you for a role, donâ€™t forget that you're also assessing whether the company is a good fit for you.

Here are a few questions to ask during your interview:

- About the role:
What will my day-to-day responsibilities look like?
How do success and performance get measured?
What would the average day look like for me, to be very successful in the position?

- About the culture:
How would you describe the team dynamic?
Whatâ€™s the work-life balance like here?
Why are you hiring for this position?
Why did you last 2 staff members leave your agency?

- About growth opportunities:
What does career progression look like at this company?
Are there opportunities for development and advancement?
What are the long terms plans for the company?

An interview is a two-way conversation. Ensure you go into an interview with a good idea of what you are looking for from your next company. Make sure you leave with the clarity you need to make an informed decision about your next step.

post_html:
Are you preparing for a job interview? Here's a comprehensive guide to help you succeed:

_Before the Interview_
1. _Research the company_: Learn about the company's mission, values, and culture.
2. _Review the job description_: Understand the job requirements and be ready to provide examples of your skills and experience.
3. _Prepare your resume and references_: Make sure your resume and references are updated and tailored to the job.

_During the Interview_
1. _Be on time_: Plan to arrive 10-15 minutes before the interview.
2. _Dress professionally_: Wear attire that is professional and consistent with the company culture.
3. _Be confident and enthusiastic_: Show your passion for the company and the role.
4. _Listen actively_: Pay attention to the interviewer's questions and respond thoughtfully.
5. _Ask questions_: Prepare a list of questions to ask the interviewer about the company and the role.

_After the Interview_
1. _Send a thank-you note_: Express your gratitude for the interviewer's time and reiterate your interest in the role.
2. _Follow up_: If you haven't heard back within a week, send a follow-up email to inquire about the status of your application.

Additional Tips
1. _Practice your responses_: Prepare answers to common interview questions.
2. _Use the STAR method_: Structure your responses using the Situation, Task, Action, and Result (STAR) method.
3. _Be honest and authentic_: Be yourself and don't exaggerate your skills or experience.

Share Your Interview Tips!
What's your top interview tip? Share with us in the comments!

post_html:
10 things NOT to say in a Job Interview,
(And what TO say instead):

Incredible resource from my friend Will McTighe ğŸ”¥
Check him out for more insights like this.

Interviews are like first dates,
Awkward and hard.

You only get 30 minutes to:

âœ… See if you're a fit.
âœ… Showcase your skills.
âœ… Show your enthusiasm.

Don't fall into the trap of sending the wrong message.

Avoid saying these 10 things:
(And what to say instead)

1/ "I don't have any questions."
â†³ Why: Shows zero preparation or interest
â†³ Instead: Ask specific questions about the team's current projects or culture

2/ "I'll take any job right now."
â†³ Why: Signals desperation, kills your negotiating power
â†³ Instead: Highlight skills that match this specific role

3/ "I don't like taking direction."
â†³ Why: Gives the impression you're uncoachable
â†³ Instead: Share how you've grown from feedback

4/ "I don't have any weaknesses."
â†³ Why: Sounds unrealistic and arrogant
â†³ Instead: Share a real weakness and how you're improving

5/ "I hate my current boss."
â†³ Why: Raises red flags about professionalism
â†³ Instead: Focus on your career growth goals

6/ "I'll figure it out as I go."
â†³ Why: Suggests you don't prepare
â†³ Instead: Emphasize your (proven) ability to learn quickly

7/ "This is a stepping stone for me."
â†³ Why: Companies don't want to invest in short-term employees
â†³ Instead: Share your interest in growing with the company

8/ "What's your work-from-home policy?" (too early)
â†³ Why: Makes work flexibility seem like your top priority
â†³ Instead: First discuss role and fit and get them interested

9/ "What time do people leave?"
â†³ Why: Implies you're just watching the clock
â†³ Instead: Ask about daily workflows and responsibilities

10/ "I don't handle stress well."
â†³ Why: Suggests you'll struggle under pressure
â†³ Instead: Describe how you organize work to manage deadlines

Remember:
Preparation and positivity go a long way.

P.S. What's your #1 interview tip that nobody talks about?

post_html:
The secret to landing that dream job? It's so simple.

NEVER USE PDFs FOR YOUR RESUME. Too easy for your prospective hiring manager to open. Make them work for it. Use a weird format like .BMP or .Tiff. This provides an air of mystery to your resume. "What could this be? How the hell do I even open a TARGA file in 2025?" Hiring managers love puzzle solving, so give them something they can really sink their teeth into.

START INTERVIEWS BY REVEALING A TRAGIC FAMILY SECRET: You can make one up if you need to. "My grandpa could have stopped Ted Bundy, but didn't" is a good one. "Every one of my uncles is a horse thief" is more niche, but there's a timeless quality to it. My tip? Have fun with it.

INSIST ON BEING PAID IN RARE JEWELS: Inflation, shmilflation! Sure, it may take a few extra steps, but nothing spends better than a sack full of sapphires, emeralds, and diamonds. Slapping down a topaz at the local five and dime is a real flex.

FORCE YOUR INTERVIEWER TO TAKE A POSITION ON MARTIN LUTHER: Divinely inspired reformer, or blasphemous oaf? Both positions are respectable, but make them take a side, and more importantly, defend it.

END WITH A SONG: Most interviewers end interviews with "Do you have any more questions?" This is when you queue up some music and say, "Just one: do you enjoy Billy Joel's middle period?" That's when you can delight them with a rendition of "Uptown Girl" or "Allentown." Don't go for B-Sides like "Big Man on Mulberry Street" or "Running on Ice" you'll just be wasting everyone's time.

Hope this helps! Feel free to leave your favorite job-landing tip below!

post_html:
A lot of advice out there when it comes to interviewing usually is focused around the candidate. What typically gets lost in the sauce is that the candidates are absolutely interviewing the Employer as well.

Employers / Hiring Managers - couple tips for you

1) Make sure you know what kind of candidate you're looking for. Define the must haves vs. nice to haves, etc.. (Be Realistic)

2) You need to be able to move quickly. Streamline an interview process, be quick about it without skipping key steps. Be Decisive.

3) Candidates are interviewing you. Sell the company. Sell the Brand. Sell the opportunity and what it is and what it can become. Tell them about your leadership style as well as the higher ups leadership style.

Interviews are a two way street. Let's go fill some roles!

post_html:
One year ago, I embarked on a nerve-wracking journey - my first "big girl job" interview at Blue Cross Blue Shield of Texas. The interview process can be scary!
Here are 5 valuable tips to help you make the most out of it:

1. Preparation is key:
Ensure you are well-prepared by conducting thorough research, preparing insightful questions, and being ready to address any queries they may pose.

2. Remember to breathe:
Taking deep breaths can help calm your nerves and allow you to collect your thoughts effectively during the interview.

3. Deliberate before you articulate:
Take a moment to process the question, formulate a thoughtful response, and avoid leaving the interview room with regrets about missed opportunities to shine.

4. Inquire with purpose:
Posing relevant and thoughtful questions demonstrates your engagement and readiness to the interviewer, leaving a positive impression.

5. Dress the part:
As the saying goes, "look good, play good." Opt for a professional attire that boosts your confidence, translating into a poised and self-assured demeanor during the interview.

post_html:
Useful Interview Tips...

I see this almost daily on here, but youâ€™d be surprised how many people still donâ€™t prep properly for their interviews.

I get itâ€”youâ€™ve been in the industry for years, you know your stuff, and you think you can wing it. But no matter how experienced or confident you feel, skipping interview prep is like turning up to a test without revising. You might pass, but why take the risk?

Tips I always give my candidates:

âœ…DO YOUR RESEARCH!!! â€“ How are you turning up to a job interview knowing nothing about the company you could be working for? Check their website, LinkedIn, recent news, and even employee reviews if you can. Make sure you can confidently talk about why you want to work there.

âœ… ALWAYS have questions to ask â€“ Itâ€™s not just about them interviewing you; youâ€™re also seeing if the role and company are the right fit for you. Ask things like: What do you enjoy about working here? Whatâ€™s kept you here for so long? Whatâ€™s the biggest challenge in this role?

âœ… Know your CV inside out â€“ If itâ€™s on your CV, be ready to talk about it. If you listed a skill, have an example of how youâ€™ve used it. If you put down responsibilities, be prepared to explain how you handled them.

âœ… Dress appropriately â€“ Sounds obvious, but first impressions count. Even if itâ€™s a casual workplace, turning up looking scruffy isnâ€™t a good look. If in doubt, always go smarter.

âœ… Be yourself â€“ Theyâ€™re hiring a person, not just a skillset. Show your personality, be professional but natural, and remember that interviews are just conversations (with slightly higher stakes).

At the end of the day, preparation = confidence. Go in knowing youâ€™ve done the work, and the rest will follow.

Not all job offers are worth accepting. Spot these red flags before you say yes!

1ï¸âƒ£ Vague Job Description â†’ Responsibilities keep changing or lack clarity.

2ï¸âƒ£ Disorganized Interview Process â†’ Late starts, unprepared interviewers, or no clear structure.

3ï¸âƒ£ High Turnover Rates â†’ The role or team frequently loses employees.

4ï¸âƒ£ Negative Talk About Former Employees â†’ Badmouthing past employees is a major red flag.

5ï¸âƒ£ Dodging Questions About Culture â†’ They avoid giving real answers about workplace values.

6ï¸âƒ£ Unrealistic Expectations â†’ Workload or skills seem impossible for one person.

7ï¸âƒ£ Micromanagement Indicators â†’ Constant check-ins, rigid approvals, or over-control.

8ï¸âƒ£ Lack of Growth Opportunities â†’ No clear path for promotions or development.

9ï¸âƒ£ Excessive Focus on Overtime â†’ They glorify long hours and late nights.

ğŸ”Ÿ Inconsistent Messaging â†’ Different interviewers give conflicting job details.

1ï¸âƒ£1ï¸âƒ£ Overemphasis on "Wearing Many Hats" â†’ A sign of boundaryless workloads.

1ï¸âƒ£2ï¸âƒ£ High-Stress Environment Indicators â†’ Praising pressure-heavy environments without real support.

1ï¸âƒ£3ï¸âƒ£ Ignoring Employee Well-Being â†’ No mention of work-life balance or benefits.

1ï¸âƒ£4ï¸âƒ£ Vague Compensation Discussions â†’ Avoiding specifics on salary, raises, or perks.

1ï¸âƒ£5ï¸âƒ£ Gut Feeling of Discomfort â†’ If something feels off, trust your instincts.

ğŸ’¡ Pro Tip: If a company checks too many of these boxes, it might be time to walk away.

Have you ever spotted red flags in an interview? Drop your experience below! â¬‡ï¸

STOP Getting Ghosted After Interviews! ğŸ”´
You spend 10+ hours preparing for interviews.
You research, rehearse, and refine your answers.

But thenâ€¦ a generic rejection email.
No feedback. No insights. No next steps. Just silence.

Hereâ€™s how to break the cycle and take back control. ğŸ‘‡

At the end of your interview, ask this one powerful question:

ğŸ’¡ "Is there anything about my resume or interview that makes you doubt Iâ€™d be a good fit for this role?"

Why? Because 70%+ of hiring managers have concerns they never voice. ğŸš¨

ğŸ”¹ This question forces them to reveal any red flags
ğŸ”¹ It gives you real-time feedback on where you stand
ğŸ”¹ You get a chance to clarify misunderstandings immediately

Instead of waiting weeks for a rejection, you get instant insights.

ğŸš€ Pro Tip: If they mention a concern, donâ€™t panic! Instead, respond with:

âœ… "Thatâ€™s a great point! Let me clarify..."
âœ… "I actually have experience with thatâ€”let me explain..."
âœ… "Iâ€™d love to share an example to address that..."

ğŸ’¡ When you handle objections live, you increase your hiring chances by 40%+.

Next time, donâ€™t just hope for an offerâ€”ask for the feedback that can get you there. ğŸ’¼ğŸ”¥

post_html:
Let's face it: interviews can be nerve-wracking. But here's the thing: you don't need to be a know-it-all to nail it!

Dear Candidates:

You don't need to know everything to pass your interview. Aim for 70-80% of the subject matter, and you're golden! Remember, no one knows 100% - not even your boss or hiring manager.

So, take a deep breath and be honest about what you know and what you don't. There's always something to learn from the other end!

Dear Hiring Managers:

Ditch the "gotcha" questions and the "I'm-the-smartest-person-in-the-room" attitude. Interviews aren't competitions; they're conversations.

You want to understand the candidate's knowledge, experience, and what they bring to the table. So, keep it real, keep it relaxed, and let's get to know each other!

Let's make interviews more human and less intimidating!

What are your thoughts on interviews? Share your experiences and tips in the comments below!

I understand both view points, one side the candidate is shy and maybe doesnt wanna open up. But I think the question is just totally misunderstood a test of what you are willing to give away.

There is nothing wrong with not being too personal and just state that you are hard working, love working with people, really working on complicated projects.

There is also a failure on the other side, why can they not lead the conversation and be a bit more warm instead of feeling like you are on trial.

I like to ask questions and get a better understanding of someone, I just want to see some passion and excitement so I feel they are someone thats human and relatable also I find that asking people questions about stuff they are passionate about just helps move the interview forward instead of being really nervy

post_html: Interview Tips for the InterviewER
post_text: Interview Tips for the InterviewER

post_html:
If you thought job hunting was competitive before, brace yourselfâ€”this new wave of job seekers is about to shake things up.

AI is eliminating jobs at a rapid pace, globalization is creating competition across the world.

In 2024, the hiring rate for positions requiring a college degree declined by 20% year-over-year.

Now 10s of thousands of federal employees are going to flood the market as well, as federal buyout go into effect.

So here are my top three interview tips from a career coach who has completed over 500+ interviews

1. Have fun. we hire people who are likable, who make us remember the joke or personal anecdote they brought to the table, who smile and appear even if its for 30 minutes happy.

2. Be confident. You're the best product you're ever going to sell. Your personality creates our personal reality, be the person who has that fantastic job.

3. Flip the interview. Interview the interviewer, make sure the questions you ask add value to the conversation and go beyond the surface level.

15 Interview RED Flags You Should Never Ignore.
(And exactly what TO ask)

Interviews are like detective work,
You're looking for clues.

You only get 30 minutes to:
â†³ Spot toxic cultures.
â†³ Find deal-breakers.
â†³ Protect your career.

Don't fall into the trap of missing warning signs.

Take a sneak peek at the interview red flags sheet:

1/ "We're like one big family here"

â†³ Why: Blurred boundaries
â†³ Tip: Probe work-life boundaries
â†³ Ask: What are your typical work hours?

2/ "We need you to wear multiple hats"

â†³ Why: Understaffed, unclear role
â†³ Tip: Get specific about duties
â†³ Ask: What's my primary focus?

â†³ Why: Empty promises
â†³ Tip: Push for clear compensation
â†³ Ask: What metrics trigger raises?

â†³ Why: Power play
â†³ Tip: Assess respect for candidates
â†³ Ask: What defines success here?

5/ "The role has changed a bit..."

â†³ Why: Bait and switch
â†³ Tip: Compare role changes
â†³ Ask: What exactly changed?

6/ "We encourage overtime"

â†³ Why: Unpaid extra work
â†³ Tip: Clarify compensation
â†³ Ask: How is overtime paid?

7/ "The job market is tough right now"

â†³ Why: Lowball tactics
â†³ Tip: Stand firm on value
â†³ Ask: What's your salary range?

8/ "We don't discuss that in interviews"

â†³ Why: Hidden info
â†³ Tip: Push for transparency
â†³ Ask: When can we discuss this?

9/ "We need flexible hours"

â†³ Why: No set schedule
â†³ Tip: Define expectations
â†³ Ask: What availability is required?

10/ "Everyone starts at the bottom here"

â†³ Why: Ignoring experience
â†³ Tip: Assert your value
â†³ Ask: How is experience valued?

11/ "We work fast and make mistakes"

â†³ Why: Stress culture
â†³ Tip: Check quality controls
â†³ Ask: How do you handle errors?

12/ "You'll get details when you start"

â†³ Why: Poor onboarding
â†³ Tip: Get training clarity
â†³ Ask: What's the onboarding like?

Top 5 resume tips that get you interviews:

1. Lead with the section of your resume with the most value.

Example: if you don't have any experience but have a Masters in Business Analytics, start your resume with your education section.

2. Show specific, numeric impact.

Example: Increased gross revenue by 3% as measure by...

âŒ don't use generic or fake percentages like 20% or 50%. If you cant measure impact, don't use a percentage.

3. Only include skills that you can validate.

Example: If you include Machine Learning in your skills section, you better have some machine learning project or experience in your resume.

4. Add the title you want to be on your resume.

Example: if you have done data analytics at a previous job, but you worked in operations, ask your previous manager if you can change the job title to data analyst on your linkedin and resume.

Nailing a job interview can feel daunting, but it doesn't have to be! Here are 5 tips to help you shine and leave a lasting impression:

1ï¸âƒ£ Do Your Homework: Research the company and the role you're seeking. Understanding the values, mission, and culture shows genuine interest and preparation.
2ï¸âƒ£ Practice Your Story: Be ready to explain your experience and achievements. Use the STAR method (Situation, Task, Action, Result) to give concise, compelling answers.
3ï¸âƒ£ Ask Questions: Remember, interviews go both ways! Prepare thoughtful questions about the role, team, and company to show you're truly invested.
4ï¸âƒ£ Master Non-Verbal Cues: Your body language speaks volumes - smile, maintain good posture, and use eye contact to exude confidence (even in virtual interviews!).
5ï¸âƒ£ Follow-Up: Send a personalized thank-you note or email. It's a simple gesture that can make a big impact!

ğŸ’¬ What's your go-to interview tip? Drop it in the comments and letâ€™s share the knowledge! ğŸ™Œ

Ace Your Interview with Confidence & Professionalism

A job interview isnâ€™t just about answering questionsâ€”itâ€™s about how you present yourself. Hereâ€™s how to leave a lasting impression:

âœ… Body Language & Attitude:

Walk in confidently, greet with a firm handshake, and smile naturally.

Maintain good posture and steady eye contact.

Stay calm, composed, and positive throughout.


âœ… What to Say & Avoid:

Keep answers clear, concise, and relevant.

Never badmouth previous employers or exaggerate skills.

Express enthusiasm and gratitude for the opportunity.


âœ… Handling Tough Questions:

If unsure, stay calm and say, "Thatâ€™s a great question! Hereâ€™s how Iâ€™d approach itâ€¦"

Show willingness to learn rather than guessing.


âœ… Final Touch:

Dress professionally, speak clearly, and exit with a confident handshake.


Confidence and authenticity make the best impression. Whatâ€™s your top interview tip? Share in the comments!

7 Interview Secrets Nobody Shares
(The real reason you're not getting hired)

Getting the job you want isn't just about skills.

It's about knowing the unwritten rules.

Smart moves paired with insider tricks make all the difference.

Here are the secrets that transform interviews into offers:

1ï¸âƒ£ Crush It Before You Show Up
â†³ Tip: Arrive an hour early to a nearby cafe.
â†³ Trick: Research your interviewer's recent wins.

2ï¸âƒ£ Make Them Remember You
â†³ Tip: Dress one level up from the company style.
â†³ Trick: Copy their energy level and speaking pace.

3ï¸âƒ£ Master The Hot Seat
â†³ Tip: Prepare 5 stories about your best work.
â†³ Trick: Take a 3-second pause before tough answers.

4ï¸âƒ£ Speak Without Words
â†³ Tip: Keep your hands visible on the table.
â†³ Trick: Mirror their sitting position slightly.

5ï¸âƒ£ Turn Tables Like a Pro
â†³ Tip: Ask about their biggest team challenges.
â†³ Trick: Turn their questions into conversations.

6ï¸âƒ£ Handle The Money Talk
â†³ Tip: Know your market value beforehand.
â†³ Trick: Let them name the first number.

7ï¸âƒ£ Leave Them Wanting More
â†³ Tip: Ask about next steps clearly.
â†³ Trick: End with "I'm even more excited about this role".

Remember:
Playing the game well is just as important as having the skills.

Which of these tricks will you try in your next interview?

Candidate Questions During the Interview Process... â“ â“ â“
A Recruiter's Perspective... ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ’»

Great interviews often end with the classic "Do you have any questions for me/us?" This is your opportunity to leave a lasting impression!

Asking thoughtful questions shows you're not only interested in the job, but you also want to ensure it's the right fit for both you and the company. A few ideas to come up with impactful questions, include researching the company and reviewing the job description.

Here are some ways to craft meaningful questions:

1. Research the Company:
Look up recent news about the company, its mission, and values. Review their website. Understand its culture and any growth or changes in operations. This will allow you to ask questions that reflect your understanding of the organizationâ€™s priorities and long-term vision.

2. Review the Job Description:
Analyze the key responsibilities and requirements listed in the job posting. Craft questions that clarify aspects of the role that are important to you, such as work schedule flexibility, team dynamics, or the companyâ€™s approach to training and development.

3. Align with Your Interests:
Think about what matters most to you in a job; whether itâ€™s career growth, work-life balance, or safety initiatives. Tailor your questions to focus on how the company supports those values, and how you can contribute in a way that aligns with your strengths.

By asking insightful questions based on your research, youâ€™ll show that youâ€™re not just looking for any job, but that youâ€™re genuinely interested in being a valuable contributor to the team. Donâ€™t hesitate to use this moment to clarify the companyâ€™s expectations and share what youâ€™re seeking in a role.

Pro-Tip: Working with a coach on interview prep can assist with developing effective questions as well. ğŸ‘

5 Things You Shouldn't Say in a Job Interview  âœ˜

Even if you had a difficult experience at your previous job, a job interview is a short window where you need to highlight your value and 'sell yourself' as a professional, rather than focusing on past negativity.

âœ˜ "My previous manager was terrible"
Comes across as a complaint and raises concerns about your ability to work in a team.
Better way to say it: "I value working in an environment with clear communication and strong leadership."

âœ˜ "The company was a chaos"
This can come across as complaining rather than showing adaptability.
Better way to say it: "I thrive in workplaces with structured processes and well-defined roles."

âœ˜ "I wasnâ€™t paid enough"
Focusing too much on salary might make it seem like thatâ€™s your only priority.
Better way to say it: "Iâ€™m looking for a role where my skills and contributions are valued."

âœ˜ "Iâ€™ll take any job"
Makes you sound desperate rather than motivated.
Better way to say it: "Iâ€™m looking for a role where I can bring value and grow professionally."

âœ˜ "I donâ€™t want to work overtime"
Could give the impression that you're unwilling to take responsibility.
Better way to say it: "I believe in maintaining a good work-life balance while delivering high-quality results."


Interviews are about how you frame your experience and approach. Instead of focusing on what didnâ€™t work in the past, highlight what youâ€™re looking for in your next role and how you can contribute.

Whatâ€™s the worst thing youâ€™ve heard someone say in an interview?

ğŸ”¥ 3 Crucial Tips to Impress the Hiring Manager

Very insightful share by Terry Danylak. Thanks much!

Here's how: ğŸ‘‡

1. Dress Smart
It tells the interviewer you have high standards and care about the job.

2. Research The Company
Two places you should pay attention to:

â–¸ The About page to learn more about the people who run it, its mission, vision, values and history.
â–¸ Products/Services page so you can answer why you want to work for the company.

3. Tell Them About Yourself
Use the S.E.A.T. framework to answer the most asked questions in the interviews.

â–¸ Skills - lead with your skills
â–¸ Experience - talk about your experience
â–¸ Achievements - showcase your achievements
â–¸ Type of person - describe your values and beliefs

ğŸ”¥ 5 Brilliant Questions To Ask At The End of The Interview

You will impress the hiring manager and make them think.

1. Could you tell me more about the team I will work with?
2. What do you enjoy most about working for this company?
3. Do you have any hesitations regarding my qualifications for this role?
4. What's the one thing I can do in this role to help your business succeed?
5. What advice would you give the successful candidate to succeed in this role?

ğŸ”¥ 7 Powerful Words That Will Get You Hired

1. Results-Oriented
This means you are focused on getting results and bringing value to the business.

2. Disciplined
This means you can work autonomously without any hand-holding.

3. Commercially-Driven
This means you understand that your job is to help grow the business.

4. Enthusiastic
This means you are energetic and excited to get work done.

5. Finisher
This means you always finish your work and have high standards.

6. Problem-Solver
This means you enjoy taking on challenges and overcoming them.

7. Collaborator
This means you work well with others and enjoy teamwork.

â€”

Use these tips, questions and words to nail your interview and get the job you want.

What I Learned From My Failed Interviews


1. First Impressions Count
-Your dress code speaks before you do.


-Dress appropriately,
how you present yourself is how people will perceive you.


2. Preparation Is Everything

-Great interviews are built on solid preparation, not last minute cramming.

-Research the company thoroughly, it shows youâ€™re genuinely interested.



3. Remember, Itâ€™s Just a Conversation.

-The hiring team is made up of people, just like you.

-Stay calm and composed ,
itâ€™s okay to feel nervous, but donâ€™t let it overwhelm you.

 -Treat the interview as a two-way conversation, not a test.



4. Confidence Leaves a Mark

- Walk in with purpose, like you already belong there.
- Believe in your abilities, it inspires trust and admiration.


Each interview, successful or not is a stepping stone. Be open to learn from it .

P.S In my previous post , two people suggested I make this a series , so letâ€™s see how that goes.

post_html:
The secret to acing your next job interview?


Preparation.

To stand out from the crowd, you want to have:
â†³In-depth knowledge of the organization and position
â†³3 main points about why you're a great candidate
â†³At least 5 stories from past jobs that show your strengths
â†³And answers to these 12 additional frequently asked questions

[Comment "More" to get Parts 1 and 2]

1) What sets you apart from other candidates?
â†³Tip: Stay focused on yourself - do not badmouth others
â†³Answer: Describe how your unique strengths are a great fit for this role

2) Are you applying to any other jobs right now?
â†³Tip: Be transparent - most people apply to multiple jobs
â†³Answer: Briefly describe where you are in any other processes and then reiterate your commitment to this position

3) How would your boss describe you in 3 words?
â†³Tip: Similar to "what are your greatest strengths"
â†³Answer: Answer with 3, 1-word strengths, but then give more detail on each one

4) Describe your approach to solving complex problems.
â†³Tip: Pick almost anything - customer issue, interpersonal problem, etc.
â†³Answer: Choose one where you broke the problem down into small steps, took action, got buy-in, and solved it

5) What's a time you had to think on your feet?
â†³Tip: This is testing your ability to stay calm while stressed
â†³Answer: Choose an example where you maintained your composure and got to the best outcome you could

6) Tell me about a time you took the initiative.
â†³Tip: Show that you have no problem starting things on your own
â†³Answer: Pick an issue that many knew about, but only you set out to solve

7) Describe a time you faced a difficult ethical decision.
â†³Tip: Speak hypothetically if you don't have a specific example
â†³Answer: Describe a time you never hesitated to take the ethical path

8) What's something you've learned in the last year?
â†³Tip: Show that you're growth-minded
â†³Answer: Describe a book you read, a training you attended, a podcast you listened to, or a mentor you sought out

9) How important is work-life balance?
â†³Tip: There's a middle ground here between balance and hard work
â†³Answer: Describe the things you love doing outside of work, while emphasizing your dedication

10) How did you learn about this job?
â†³Tip: If you know someone at the company, or were recruited, mention that
â†³Answer: Say how you found out, and then explain the excitement you felt

11) What would you focus on in your first 90 days?
â†³Tip: Balance taking the initiative and keeping an open mind
â†³Answer: Describe a few things you'd want to tackle early, and a few you'd want to learn

12) What does your typical day look like?
â†³Tip: Show the genuine you, but skip boring details
â†³Answer: Describe the things you enjoy and that give you energy


Make sure you prepare enough to use every question as an opportunity to show why you're the strongest candidate.

Good luck!

---

â™» Repost to help those in your network who are interviewing.

And follow me George Stern for more content like this.

Mastering Online Interviews: Tips for Success

The rise of virtual hiring has made online interviews a crucial part of the recruitment process. While they offer flexibility and efficiency, they also come with unique challenges.

Here are a few key tips to make a strong impression in your next online interview:
âœ… Test Your Tech â€“ Ensure your internet connection, camera and microphone are working properly. Log in early to troubleshoot any issues.
âœ… Set the Scene â€“ A quiet, well-lit space with minimal distractions helps keep the focus on you.
âœ… Dress Professionally â€“ Treat it like an in-person meeting. First impressions still matter!
âœ… Mind Your Body Language â€“ Maintain eye contact by looking at the camera, sit up straight and use natural gestures.
âœ… Be Ready for the Unexpected â€“ Technical glitches happen. Stay calm and have a backup plan, like a phone number to call in case of issues.
âœ… Engage and Follow Up â€“ Show enthusiasm, ask thoughtful questions and send a thank-you note afterward.

Online interviews are here to stay and mastering them can give you a competitive edge.

post_html:
Why rambling on interviews can be holding you back.

Rambling during an interview is a common issue that can affect your progress in the hiring process. The candidates who stand out are able to communicate their experiences and skills in a clear, concise, and engaging way.

Early in my career, I struggled with this too, whether it was in interviews, presentations, or networking. Itâ€™s easy to ramble when youâ€™re nervous, or trying to fill silence. But over time, I learned a few key strategies that helped me keep my responses focused and impactful.

Here are some tips that helped me:

1. Practice Positive Affirmations

Before any interview or presentation, take a moment to remind yourself that you deserve this opportunity, that you're knowledgeable, and that you're ready. Positive affirmations help calm your nerves, reduce anxiety, and give you the confidence to express yourself clearly.

2. Slow Down Your Speech

It may sound counterintuitive, but slowing down your speaking pace can make a huge difference. When you talk too fast, it's easy to stumble over words or add unnecessary filler. Slowing down not only gives you time to think but also helps you sound more thoughtful and deliberate.

3. Record Yourself

Recording yourself can feel awkward, but itâ€™s one of the most effective ways to improve. Listening to your responses will help you identify areas where you can refine your delivery. If listening to yourself feels uncomfortable, try practicing with a friend for feedback.

post_text:
Why rambling on interviews can be holding you back. 

Rambling during an interview is a common issue that can affect your progress in the hiring process. The candidates who stand out are able to communicate their experiences and skills in a clear, concise, and engaging way.

Early in my career, I struggled with this too, whether it was in interviews, presentations, or networking. Itâ€™s easy to ramble when youâ€™re nervous, or trying to fill silence. But over time, I learned a few key strategies that helped me keep my responses focused and impactful.

Here are some tips that helped me:

1. Practice Positive Affirmations

Before any interview or presentation, take a moment to remind yourself that you deserve this opportunity, that you're knowledgeable, and that you're ready. Positive affirmations help calm your nerves, reduce anxiety, and give you the confidence to express yourself clearly.

2. Slow Down Your Speech

It may sound counterintuitive, but slowing down your speaking pace can make a huge difference. When you talk too fast, it's easy to stumble over words or add unnecessary filler. Slowing down not only gives you time to think but also helps you sound more thoughtful and deliberate.

3. Record Yourself

Recording yourself can feel awkward, but itâ€™s one of the most effective ways to improve. Listening to your responses will help you identify areas where you can refine your delivery. If listening to yourself feels uncomfortable, try practicing with a friend for feedback.

Try these tips next time you have an interview or a big presentation and remember this will take practice so don't be hard on yourself.

ğŸŒŸ Ready to Ace Your Interviews? ğŸŒŸ

As a recruiter, I frequently get asked about ways to set yourself apart and prepare for interviews. Here are some essential tips to help you shine:

1. Research the Company and the Role: Understand the company's mission, values, and culture, as well as the specific role you're applying for. This shows your genuine interest and helps you tailor your answers to align with the company's goals. Dive into their website, read recent news articles, and check out their social media to get a sense of their current projects and initiatives.

2ï¸. Practice Common Questions: Prepare answers for typical interview questions. Think about your experiences and how they relate to the role.

3. Dress the Part: First impressions matter! Choose an outfit that reflects professionalism.

4ï¸. Ask Questions: Interviews are a two-way street. Prepare thoughtful questions to ask your interviewer. This demonstrates your interest in the role and helps you assess if the company is the right fit for you.

5ï¸. Follow Up: Send a thank-you email after the interview to express your appreciation. It sets you apart!

One crucial aspect of interview preparation is knowing how to answer common interview questions effectively. Check out this article from The Muse for valuable insights on how to tackle those tricky questions:

 ğŸ“š https://lnkd.in/gMUU2ySZ

Good luck, and go get 'em! ğŸ’ªâœ¨

post_html:
A tip you didn't ask for but may need:

Interview prep goes a long way.

A quick Google search on a brand may be the deciding factor between you and another candidate.

For context, if I'm interviewing 2 candidates and one of them knows nothing about our brand and the other is familiar with our product line or knows a couple places where we sell our products......guess who's going to be the front runner? The person who did a quick search on what kind of company they were applying to.

Are you expected to be an expert? absolutely not!

But next time a recruiter or hiring manager asks "How did you first hear about us" or "What stood out to you about this role compared to others", you'll be prepared. Lasting impressions are built on confidence.

post_html:
ğŸ§ Common interview mistakes and how to avoid them

ğŸ‘‰ Lack of preparation
Candidates often fail to research the company. Read up on their history, mission, and recent news. This shows genuine interest and can set you apart.

ğŸ‘‰ Overlooking the job description
Make sure you understand the role requirements deeply. Highlight how your experience and skills align with what they need.

ğŸ‘‰ Poor body language
Slouching, avoiding eye contact, or fidgeting can send negative signals. Practise confident, calm, and positive body language.

ğŸ‘‰ Talking too much (or too little)
Aim for balanced responses. Be concise but provide enough detail to showcase your abilities. It's a conversation, not a monologue.

ğŸ‘‰ Not asking questions
Show curiosity and engagement by asking insightful questions about the role and the company. It shows you're seriously considering the position.

ğŸ‘‰ Ignoring cultural fit
Researching the company's culture can help you assess if you'd thrive there. Mention how your values align with theirs.

Remember, interviews are as much about fit as they are about skills. Be prepared, be yourself, and good luck!

Feel free to share your own interview tips in the comments or visit www.calibrecandidates.com for more advice.

Nailing your interview is as much about what NOT to do as it is about what to do. Here are the top mistakes that can sabotage your chances:

1ï¸âƒ£ Arriving late â€“ First impressions matter. Respect the interviewerâ€™s time.
2ï¸âƒ£ Wearing the wrong clothes â€“ Dress for the job you want. Keep it professional!
3ï¸âƒ£ Low self-confidence â€“ Speak clearly, maintain eye contact, and project confidence.
4ï¸âƒ£ Showing stress â€“ Stay calm and composed. Deep breaths work wonders.

ğŸ’¥ğŸ’¥ğŸ’¥Interviewing 101ğŸ’¥ğŸ’¥ğŸ’¥

Here are the top tips/ tricks I like to relay to candidates before they interview with one of my clients.

1. Do your research so you can speak to why you are interested in THIS company and THIS role. Review the companyâ€™s website. Look at the interviewerâ€™s LI profile so you understand their background. Be prepared with examples of how your experience aligns with the bullet points on the job description.

2. Dress to impress. Dress to impress. Dress to impress. Our culture has gone quite casual since COVID, but Iâ€™d rather you be overdressed for the interview than underdressed. You can get casual once youâ€™ve gotten the job.

3. Come prepared with a ton of questions. Yes, you will likely get the majority of those questions answered simply through the conversation, but itâ€™s important to have questions prepared so at the end of the interview, when the interviewer asks you what questions you have, you have some!

4. You CAN have questions/ thoughts written out next to you (shocker!) An interview is not a test. Consulting your padfolio for questions or thoughts shows that you have done your prep for the interview, have invested the time and are truly interested.

5. If still interested in the opportunity as the interview wraps up, let the interviewer know at the end of the interview! I think a lot of candidates get superstitious and want to hold their excitement close to the vest. People hire people they like. And people like people who want to work with them! So if you are interested, let them know.

6. Send a thank you email by EOD. Itâ€™s noticeable if you donâ€™t. Take the five minutes and send one.

7. An interview is as much for you as it is for the client. Itâ€™s totally okay to interview and conclude you arenâ€™t interested in moving forward.

I send these, as well as additional tips and attachments, to every candidate that is interviewing for a job through me. If youâ€™d be interested in a copy of my standard prep email, please let me know â€“ just shoot me an email or comment here and I can get it in your inbox.

Happy interviewing!

29/100

post_html:
5 INTERVIEW PREPARATION TIPS

It amazes me that candidates are often badly prepared for interviews.

This is your chance to make an impact.

So beyond the obvious here are 5 INTERVIEW PREPARATION TIPS

1. Treat the interview as a BUSINESS MEETING - so plenty of preparation on the company and interviewers.
2. Don't have a cosy chat. Prepare objectives. Decide on the 4 or 5 things you can offer the employer and prepare tangible examples of each.
3. Decide on the 4 or 5 things you want to discover and prepare your questions. This could be more about the role, culture, people, way of working, future plans.
4. Be ready at the start. First impressions are key - so be prepared at least 5 minutes before the interview starts.
5. Prepare your closing statement. What are you going to say if you are positive about the interview and want to progress?

hashtag#interviews
hashtag#careers
